The first consideration for the answer to this question is whether the famine will occur, and only then whether the UN will declare it within the set time frame. And, spoiler alert, my prediction will be based primarily on the assessment of the first part because altogether I don't think the areas will fulfil the requirements of famine and therefore there will be nothing to declare. But all in order: I take the qualification of "famine" from the article from FEWS (the 5 levels of food insecurity, 5 being "famine") which seems to be a standard metrics in the domain. Looking at the trends in the East Africa region, Kenya, Uganda, and Tanzania are out of the question, the situation is getting better and no large areas reach more than level 2. It comes down to Ethiopia and Somalia, the latter being hit the most. Now FEWS, which is a tool designed to predict the severity of food insecurity states that yes, large parts of these two will be in "crisis", but that is still two levels away from "famine". There was a significant deterioration due to the infamous locust infestation, but even after accounting for that, the tool concluded that the situation will not go as far as to "famine". And given how rare such events are, the conclusion seems reasonable. The baseline is therefore fairly low, though the known and uknown unknowns must be accounted for. 5%. What would have to happen for a famine to be declared in one of these countries? Probably a few things at the same time, as individual factors didn't in the past seem to have the effect of turning areas from "stressed" (lvl2) or "crisis" (lvl3), into "famine" (lvl5) in just a few months. Some of the most likely factors are cuts in humanitarian aid, Covid measures, conflict trends, and unexpected weather. Starting from the last, Somalia, which was one of the worst-hit countries is expecting some seasonal rains and harvests (https://fews.net/east-africa/somalia), ethiopia apparently might face under-average harvest in oct-dec 2020 season. The level of conflict in Somalia is high, but hasn't changed in a while. Covid grew in Ethiopia recently but started subsiding again and the measures in place seem to make sure that production\import of basic goods in ensured (https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ethiopia/coronavirus), Somalia's data don't indicate that there is a growth or that it worries the authorities too much.   Individually I find these factors' impact on food security in the foreseeable future to be nothing out of the ordinary, and altogether the likelihood of them occurring at the same time feels quite low. This is obviously a theoretical and untested claim, but for the sake of this eyeballed analysis, I will go with it. 7%.

Another month passes. Decreasing the forecast accordingly but not by very much because the risk of famine is still high. It is the timeline that is unclear. There is likely to be a lag between poor harvests (and other factors) and famine being reported.

For the UN to declare famine certain criteria have to be met:
•	At least 20 percent of households in a given area face extreme food shortages with limited ability to cope.
•	More than 30 percent of children suffer from acute malnutrition.
•	Hunger causes more than two deaths each day for every 10,000 people. (https://www.worldvision.org/hunger-news-stories/africa-hunger-famine-facts#famine) The last famine listed was in 2017 in Sudan. The last time a famine was declared by the UN in East Africa was in 2011, and it was the first to be declared in the Horn in 30 years (Ethiopia's famine in the 1980s). Usually famine goes hand-in-hand with war, but Somalia but all the countries listed are not at war, nor look to be, any time soon. The only time that it seems famine was caused by locusts was in 1915-1918 under the Mount Lebanon Famine, but this was also during WWI/blockade. So while the locusts are a problem, they are a problem because of an exceptionally good rainy season. Tens of thousands of hectares have already been treated to kill the locusts. This likely wont be enough, but unless there is another significant factor (of which I don't believe there is at this point) then these three countries will be free from famine in 2020. The base rate of famines declared by the UN in the 2010s is 20% (2 in 10 years), 10% if you're restricting this to East Africa alone. Given the anomalous events this year – namely the locust swarms and covid – we've updated this prior by 3.5x. The FEWS predictions suggest that the regions in question are at least 2 phases away from famine.

The base-rate on previous famine declarations on a skim in these countries is ~3 times in the last decade.  Regrettably, the extraordinary events in the remainder of this year (i.e. unusually bad locust swarms which seem likely to impede on areas which are already food emergencies, COVID-19, whose impact both direct and indirect is worrying) leads me to boost this by a little over a factor of 2. Some of the uncertainty is in the wider world, but a fair amount of it is inside my own head (i.e. how much crisis areas rely on outside assistance, and so which adverse factors should be weighed more heavily). I hope to be pleasantly surprised.
